awd_titl_txt: Five Year Request for East Coast Winch Pool Facility (CY16-20) Year 1
awd_abstract_narration:
A request is made by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution to fund the operation of the East Coast Winch Pool. The investment in overboarding equipment is an expensive undertaking due to the high cost of purchase, maintenance and shipping of these systems. In an effort to not only ensure that these systems are available to researchers for their work but to also ensure that that they are properly maintained and available to the entire science community with expert support, NSF created the East Coast Winch Pool. This ?pool? was created to offer scientists a convenient single point of contact for all of their overboarding equipment needs as well as the expertise to provide them with creative engineering solutions for their unique requirements while at the same time reducing cost by pooling equipment for use by the scientific community.

In 2009 NSF assigned the operation of the East Coast Winch Pool to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. The range of responsibilities included:
?	Single point of contact for overboarding systems
?	Act as a center of expertise in winch use, maintenance and engineering support
?	Provide portable winch systems in support of oceanographic research
?	Provide expertise in tension member spooling for both portable and shipboard
?	systems and the personnel to operate spooling equipment
?	Maintain winches, spooling and overboarding equipment in top condition
?	Schedule the use of equipment
?	Provide shipping and handling logistics to get equipment to where it is needed
?	Provide expertise for system setup and testing in the field
?	Maintain, operate and provide UNOLS Long Core System
?	Maintain, operate and provide Jason ROV launch and recovery system

Six years since the formation of the pool, scientists, technicians and ship operators
have come to recognize the pool as a center of expertise and a source of over-boarding
systems with the reliability they expect in the harsh conditions that performing field work
often presents. This proposal seeks the funds to cover five main objectives.
1) Provide technical expertise for engineering analysis, winch maintenance, and winch training.
2) Maintain the parts, supplies and tools required to keep equipment operating.
3) Adapt systems to specific scientific requirements through engineering, updating and modification.
4) Identify the needs of the scientific community and procure the necessary new equipment.
5) Provide for the scheduling, mobilization, demobilization, shipping, and logistics of Pool assets.

por.por_cntn:
The East Coast Winch Pool, located in Woods Hole, MA at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, provides overboarding equipment (winches, a-frames, blocks, etc) to the UNOLS fleet and scientific community at large. These pooled resources allow researchers to conduct their work utilizing state of the art equipment back by a highly skilled support staff ensuring that the equipment is in top functioning condition when it arrives at the vessel or other work site. By pooling the equipment, we reduce the cost to the National Science Foundation, eliminating the need for each researcher to acquire their own very expensive winch to complete their goals. Our staff are available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week while the gear is deployed should there be problem that needs to be addressed.

The staff of the ECWP continually works to improve reliability and to modernize our equipment to meet the demands of science. Examples of this dedication include adapting some of our winches with network hubs which allows our engineer to diagnose problems and make changes to system setting remotely utilizing the internet via satellite communications systems on board our research vessels. Our staff have even designed a revolutionary new winch system that has been patented and licensed to a winch manufacturer for production and sale worldwide. Royalties from the sales of this new system come directly back to the winch pool to offset cost to NSF.

Another function of the ECWP has been to support the winding of new strength members on to UNOLS and NOAA vessel winches. As these strength members become worn or damaged it needs to be removed and replaced with new wire. This new wire needs to be wound on to the winches under a unique tension dependent upon the wire specifications and it needs to be lubricated to protect it from the harsh environment it is used in. Our large wire tension systems and support staff can be deployed to support this work in ports around the country.

Over the past 5 years the ECWP has supported hundreds of research projects and dozens of scientists both at sea and in remote areas of Antarctica. Being located at WHOI offers us the support of numerous specialized groups such as our shipping department, welding shop, machine shop, in house electricians, carpenter shop and on campus stock room. These groups help us save time and money and provide expertise we can tap into on an as needed basis. Without the ECWP and the support of WHOI?s various in house shops, deploying gear at sea would become a much more expensive, dangerous and less reliable endeavor for all involved.


Last Modified: 10/07/2022
Modified by: David C Fisichella
